title: Smith defiant on his tough approach
text:
Video Image Was Smith pushed? 9:16 NRL: Jimmy Smith joins Fox Sports News to discuss NRL CEO Dave Smith's resignation from his post.
October 20th 2015 6 hours ago /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/NRL/ Departing NRL CEO Dave Smith defiant on tough approach. Pic Stephen Cooper
NICK WALSHAW The Daily Telegraph DAVE Smith makes no apologies for the bullish leadership style which not only dominated his reign as NRL CEO, but which has also been blamed for ending it.
Speaking with The Daily Telegraph o Tuesday night, Smith defended his handling of the unfinished, and heavily criticised TV broadcasting deal, which he was hoping would settle for $1.7 billion.
The former Welsh banker also denied suggestions he was being forced out of his role prematurely because Fox Sports, who are yet to re-sign for the sport’s broadcast rights, were refusing to deal with him.
Asked if Fox executives had been disrespected during negotiations, Smith replied: “At the end of the day, these are commercial negotiations.
“And that means we have to do best by the game — not just financially but fans, grassroots, all that stuff.
“And, no, you’d never seek to disenfranchise anybody through that process. But it’s a commercial negotiation and sometimes they can be ... sometimes they can take a bit longer and sometimes people may not necessarily feel like they won.”

Quizzed on suggestions Fox executives would no longer deal with him, NRL chairman John Grant — also seated in on the interview — interjected.
ARLC Chairman John Grant with Dave Smith at NRL Central announcing he is resigning as CEO of the NRL. Picture. Phil Hillyard Source: News Corp Australia
“We need to cut this off because we’re in negotiations (with Fox) at the moment,’’ Grant said. “We’re progressing discussions with them and other providers right now, so that suggestion doesn’t stack up.”
But the suggestion is, negotiations are now continuing because the CEO is gone, right?
“They’ve never stopped,’’ Smith said, continuing. “There’s commercial confidence here so we have to be a bit careful.
“But it’s true to say we’ve been dealing at the senior level constructively for a long time. And we continue to do that.
Who should replace Dave Smith as NRL CEO? “There’s no change. It is what it is ... and it’s at the most senior level.
“So I’m not exactly sure how it can get more constructive or more senior.”
And as for his leadership style, developed in the ruthless banking realm, being too much for senior league types?
“Of course, I’m always driven to get the right outcome for our fans,’’ Smith said. “Always.

“That’s my job — John’s job too. And we’ll always be forceful when it comes to protecting the interests of the game. But that’s a normal commercial negotiation.”
Despite failing to complete the deal under his tenure, Smith also insisted the NRL would eventually sign off on a contract worthy of the “Formula One of contact sport”.
“And if I didn’t think we were going to get a great deal, the right deal, I wouldn’t be leaving,’’ Smith said. “But we will, and I am.”
